text: you meet certain people and how do you
explain it I do this sometimes with my
students to try to get them to to read a
film to think about what is it about the
hair what is it about the face is it a
smell this is a smile is it the sound of
the voice 22 years ago I went to give a
lecture at the University of Oregon I
went down after the lecture to ask him a
question I suggested we take a walk to
discuss this question I was immediately
smitten I think I fell in love at that
moment but he was involved with someone
in Missouri I went back to Chicago and
really had virtually no contact when he
called me two years later out of the
blue
it was just like lightning struck and I
learned that his partner in Missouri had
developed a brain tumor
so Ron had left his dissertation and
moved back to Missouri and nurse this
guy through the last nine months of his
life talk about being faithful to your
partner the fact that he did that says
something so profound to me about Ron's
decency and what he's like as a man
after Tom's death I felt completely
isolated in Springfield Missouri I was
taking the laundry down to the basement
and halfway through getting there I
started sobbing it almost was like
animal-like in its deepness it was at
that moment that I said to myself call
George and the minute I saw George it
was immediate I realized I was in love
we've been a few weeks he'd moved in
with me in Chicago and that was 20 years
ago getting married was never a burning
aspiration of mine I'm really not sure
how much of it is because I'm a gay
person of a certain generation so when I
was coming out it just simply was not
and imaginative possibility a completely
unexpected part of my career asset over
the course the last decade I've been an
expert witness and more than a dozen
cases challenging the ban on same-sex
couples getting married
I testify primarily about the history of
anti-gay discrimination probably most
significantly the Supreme Court case
that overturned the Defense of Marriage
Act and also a case in which the Supreme
Court ruled against prop 8 there were
definitely times and you know the
lawyers I worked with or other people
who knew I was involved in these
marriage cases wondered why I wasn't
married myself but you know my testimony
wasn't about my personal feelings about
marriage when marriage was legalized in
Connecticut it was still only a few
states where it was imaginable and it's
as if you're doing it for a political
reason at that point I didn't want to
get married under those circumstances
but I think after the Supreme Court
decision I evolved along with Obama I
have learned through my involvement in
all these cases if there is something
about marriage being a moment to
recommit yourselves and stepping down
opening a new door a new stage in the
relationship it brings you into a level
of consciousness that even though we've
lived together for 20 years we've never
had that moment that really brought you
into defining and professing a love in
the way that poetry and vowels do and
that's been pretty profound
Oh
